results.headline: A Family Finds There’s Something Out There
results.summary_short: A family has an adventure in “Alien Abduction,” a sci-fi film inspired by so-called sightings in the Brown Mountain area of North Carolina.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alien Abduction

results.headline: Broadcast News: British Airhead Still Has a Platform
results.summary_short: Directed by Declan Lowney, “Alan Partridge” is the first feature film about the title character, a vapid, self-absorbed broadcaster long played by the British actor Steve Coogan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alan Partridge

results.headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
results.summary_short: “10 Rules for Sleeping Around,” about one couple who allow each other to fool around and another that doesn’t, combines nudity and jokes, but fails to be a sex comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Rules for Sleeping Around

results.display_title: The Unknown Known: The Life And Times Of Donald Rumsfeld
results.headline: Not Giving an Inch in a Battle of Wits and Words
results.summary_short: In his documentary “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris goes mano a mano with the former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unknown Known: The Life And Times Of Donald Rumsfeld

results.headline: The Profits and Losses of Fugitive Tracking
results.summary_short: In “The Retrieval,” written and directed by Chris Eska, a black youngster working for Civil War bounty hunters helps them capture black fugitives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Retrieval

results.headline: Good Wine, Bad Companions and a Nude Stroll in an Olive Grove
results.summary_short: “Dom Hemingway,” a violent British comedy, stars Jude Law as a recently released prisoner off to a French villa to get what’s coming to him — in a good way — from a gangland boss.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dom Hemingway

results.headline: A Rock Star and a Roadie, Brothers After All
results.summary_short: A scruffy documentary of the band the National’s 2010-11 European tour is less about the music than about left-field interviews with bemused band members.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mistaken for Strangers

results.headline: Facing Eviction, He Can’t Resist a Dare
results.summary_short: “Cheap Thrills” is a dark comedy about two friends who fall into a rough game with a wealthy couple they meet at a bar.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cheap Thrills

results.headline: A Boyhood Summer of Darkness
results.summary_short: Daniel Patrick Carbone’s haunting debut feature offers a dark vision of boyhood adventure in a great outdoors fraught with peril.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hide Your Smiling Faces

results.headline: Rain, Heavy at Times
results.summary_short: Russell Crowe stars in “Noah,” Darren Aronofsky’s adaptation of the Old Testament story, which brings blockbuster spectacle and narrative liberties to the story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noah

results.headline: When ‘Egyptian’ Just Meant Egyptian
results.summary_short: The documentary “Jews of Egypt” focuses on a shift from tolerance to harassment and expulsions, starting in 1949.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jews of Egypt

results.headline: Nonstop Carnage, Indonesian-Style
results.summary_short: Neither the undercover drama in “The Raid 2” nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down its numerous bracing and bloody brawls.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Raid 2: Berandal

results.headline: She’s Not Heavy, She’s My Bar Pickup
results.summary_short: “Refuge,” starring Krysten Ritter, depicts a young woman who finds a new boyfriend while raising her needy younger siblings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Refuge

results.headline: A Loopy Stalker, Protesting Her Innocence
results.summary_short: In “Nothing Without You,” a delusional woman who stalks powerful men is accused of a brutal killing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Without You

results.headline: Dreamy Postcards From Limbo
results.summary_short: The director Aaron Schimberg forays into lo-fi anachronism in his new film, “Go Down Death.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go Down Death

results.headline: He Died Laughing (Isn’t That Sweet?)
results.summary_short: In “Blumenthal,” family members react less than nobly when a garrulous playwright dies while laughing at one of his own jokes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blumenthal

results.headline: Amid Chants of ‘¡Huelga!,’ an Embodiment of Hope
results.summary_short: Diego Luna’s “Cesar Chavez” reconstructs the emergence of the United Farm Workers organization in the 1960s and focuses on the movement’s leader, who died in 1993.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cesar Chavez

results.headline: Gang Wars, Iraq Warfare
results.summary_short: “Greencard Warriors” follows a family that will do almost anything for papers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greencard Warriors

results.headline: The Nanny as Sphinx, Weaving Enigmatic Magic on the Sly
results.summary_short: “Finding Vivian Maier” focuses on a mysterious nanny who photographed Chicago scenes in the 1950s and ’60s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Vivian Maier

results.headline: Temptation in Suburbia, Amid a Midlife Crisis
results.summary_short: In “Breathe In,” directed by Drake Doremus, a marriage is threatened by a glamorous interloper who stirs up a quietly suffering husband’s deepest longings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breathe In
